jparsec.graph.chartRendering

Class RenderPlanet

  • java.lang.Object
    • jparsec.graph.chartRendering.RenderPlanet

  • public class RenderPlanet
extends java.lang.Object
    A class for planetary rendering.

    This class performs planetary renderings using models taken from the textures directory. The modelization is quite complete, taking into account the position of the observer, the object, and the Sun in the space. Illumination is applied to create a fotorealistic image, and the planetary rings are modeled taking into account their colors, transparency, and angle of illumination. The result can be improved just a little (opacity inside rings, elevation effects in surfaces, ...), but it will not differ so much from the results obtained with professional rendering tools.

    In addition, it is possible to simulate the objects as they would be observed through certain telescope, by modelizing also the difraction effects. This modelization takes into account possible chromatic aberration, but it is not fully accurate, so it's serves only as an approximation supposing a perfect aligned telescope and a very clear atmosphere.

    Models comes from Björn Jónsson & David Seal http://maps.jpl.nasa.gov. The model for Mercury is from James Hastings http://gw.marketingden.com/planets/planets.html. Some models for the moons comes from Celestia software.

    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    T. Alonso Albi - OAN (Spain)

        Position where the planet will be rendered in pixels.

      • illuminateMoonByEarth

        public boolean illuminateMoonByEarth
        True to simulate Earth illuminating Moon's dark side.

      • MAXIMUM_TEXTURE_QUALITY_FACTOR

        public static float MAXIMUM_TEXTURE_QUALITY_FACTOR
        This variable holds how many times the size of the rendering window is increased to calculate the output image (reduced by the same amount before showing) to obtain a smoothed output image. The more the number the more the quality of the output, but more computing time. This factor is only used if PlanetRenderElement.highQuality is set to true. Default value is 1.5. 2 is good to improve quality, and 1 to disable high quality mode. The rest of possible values are not so useful. In particular, values below 1 are possible to produce fast renderings, but quality will be highly degraded.

      • ALLOW_SPLINE_RESIZING

        public static boolean ALLOW_SPLINE_RESIZING
        True to allow using an spline technique (in case the instance of Graphics supports it) to resize the image in high quality mode. Default value is false, which gives better (besides much faster) results when the background is white, for instance. It is very rare the cases when false gives better output, but it is useful to improve a lot performance in big renderings, while reducing quality just a bit. Set to true for high quality (and slow) resizing.

      • FORCE_WHITE_BACKGROUND

        public static boolean FORCE_WHITE_BACKGROUND
        This flag allows to force the background color to white before applying some scaling operations to the rendering, allowing for better output quality in case the desired background is white. In this case, set this flag to true and the background color to black. This has no effect in case anaglyph mode is selected.

      • FORCE_HIGHT_QUALITY

        public static boolean FORCE_HIGHT_QUALITY
        For fields of view larger than 1 deg the high quality mode is automatically disabled to prevent artifacts when rendering the sky. These artifacts occurs when dragging a planet with other lines (constellations for instance) on the screen, due to field rotation. In case you are rendering one frame, or one after another (without repainting fast a planet and dragging it) you can set this flag to true to allow high quality rendering on large fields of view, useful to create movies of planets as visible from their satellites. Default value for this flag is false.

      • setJupiterGRSLongitude

        public void setJupiterGRSLongitude(double GRS_lon,
                          int system)
        Sets the longitude of Jupiter's Great Red Spot.

        Please note that the rendering will use the default value of the longitude of central meridian for rendering. This value is refered to System III for giant planets (rotation of the magnetic field), so the apparent rotation will not match that of the observed equatorial nor tropical belts in these planets. This function is intended to adjust specifically the apparent sight of Jupiter's disk.

        Parameters:
        GRS_lon - Observed longitude in radians. Typically obtained for a given date calling MainEvents.getJupiterGRSLongitude(double).
        system - System of coordinates of GRS_lon, 1, 2, or 3. Will be usually 2, since the Great Red Spot is in the tropical belt (1 refers to equatorial belt, and 3 to the rotation of the magnetic field).

      • getPlanetographicPosition

        public LocationElement getPlanetographicPosition(int x,
                                        int y,
                                        int coordinate_system,
                                        boolean considerSatellites)
                                          throws JPARSECException
        Obtains planetographic, selenographic, or heliographic position for certain screen coordinates. Satellites are optionally considered.
        Parameters:
        x - Screen horizontal position in pixels.
        y - Screen vertical position in pixels.
        coordinate_system - Reference coordinate system, only for giant planets: 1 (system I), 2 (system II), 3 (system III).
        considerSatellites - True to consider satellites. If a satellite is transiting on (x, y) then the position on that satellite will be returned.
        Returns:
        The corresponding position if it is on the planet, or default object (zero) else.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If an error occurs.

      • getPlanetInScreenCoordinates

        public Target.TARGET getPlanetInScreenCoordinates(int x,
                                         int y,
                                         boolean considerSatellites,
                                         int minimumSize)
                                           throws JPARSECException
        Obtain ID constant of an object in certain screen position. For a valid output it is previously necessary to render the sky, and the object must be visible.
        Parameters:
        x - Horizontal position in the rendering in pixels.
        y - Horizontal position in the rendering in pixels.
        considerSatellites - True to consider possible transiting satellites, false to ignore them.
        minimumSize - Minimum size in pixels of the planet to consider it as identified for the input coordinates. Set to 0 to allow identifying planets event when their disks are almost invisible because of their minimum apparent sizes.
        Returns:
        ID value of the object, or Target.TARGET.NOT_A_PLANET if no object is found.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If an error occurs.

      • getClosestPlanetInScreenCoordinates

        public java.lang.Object[] getClosestPlanetInScreenCoordinates(int x,
                                                     int y,
                                                     boolean considerSatellites)
                                                       throws JPARSECException
        Obtain ID constant of the solar system object closest to certain screen position. For a valid output it is previously necessary to render the sky, and the object must be visible.
        Parameters:
        x - Horizontal position in the rendering in pixels.
        y - Horizontal position in the rendering in pixels.
        considerSatellites - True to consider possible transiting satellites, false to ignore them.
        Returns:
        A array with two values (null if no object is found):
        ID value (TARGET) of the object.
        Minimum distance (Double) to the input position in pixels.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If an error occurs.

      • getScreenCoordinatesOfPlanetographicPosition

        public float[] getScreenCoordinatesOfPlanetographicPosition(LocationElement loc,
                                                   int coordinate_system,
                                                   boolean only_if_visible)
                                                     throws JPARSECException
        Obtain screen coordinates of a given planetographic, heliographic, or selenographic position in the current rendered body. Satellites are not considered.
        Parameters:
        loc - Planetographic/heliographic/selenographic coordinates on the object.
        coordinate_system - Reference coordinate system of input coordinates, only for giant planets: 1 (system I), 2 (system II), 3 (system III).
        only_if_visible - True for returning coordinates only if the input position is visible.
        Returns:
        Corresponding position in the sky, or (0, 0) if the object is not visible or the position is not visible and only_if_visible is set to true.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If an error occurs.

      • getScreenCoordinatesOfPlanetographicPosition

        public float[] getScreenCoordinatesOfPlanetographicPosition(LocationElement loc,
                                                   Target.TARGET target,
                                                   int coordinate_system,
                                                   boolean only_if_visible)
                                                     throws JPARSECException
        Obtain screen coordinates of a given planetographic, heliographic, or selenographic position in the selected body.
        Parameters:
        loc - Planetographic/heliographic/selenographic coordinates on the object.
        target - The target body, can be a satellite.
        coordinate_system - Reference coordinate system of input coordinates, only for giant planets: 1 (system I), 2 (system II), 3 (system III).
        only_if_visible - True for returning coordinates only if the input position is visible.
        Returns:
        Corresponding position in the sky, or null if the object is not visible or the position is not visible and only_if_visible is set to true.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If an error occurs.

      • identifyFeature

        public java.lang.String identifyFeature(int x,
                               int y,
                               boolean considerSatellites,
                               int minimumSize,
                               double maxDist)
        Identifies a feature in the current rendered body. GRS in Jupiter is identified in this method.
        Parameters:
        x - Window x position.
        y - Window y position.
        considerSatellites - True to consider satellites.
        minimumSize - Minimum size in pixels of the planet to consider it as identified for the input coordinates. Set to 0 to allow identifying planets event when their disks are almost invisible because of their minimum apparent sizes.
        maxDist - Maximum distance to the feature in degrees. In case no feature is closer to the input position than this value, null will be returned. Set to 0 (or a very high value) to disable this limitation.
        Returns:
        Name of the most closer feature, or null if none can be found. The name is returned as the feature name and some data between brackets, like feature type, longitude, and latitude.

      • identifyFeature

        public static java.lang.String identifyFeature(LocationElement loc,
                               Target.TARGET target,
                               double maxDist)
        Identifies a feature in the current rendered body. GRS in Jupiter is not identified in this method.
        Parameters:
        loc - Planetographic/selenographic/satellitographic position.
        target - Target body.
        maxDist - Maximum distance to the feature in degrees. In case no feature is closer to the input position than this value, null will be returned. Set to 0 (or a very high value) to disable this limitation.
        Returns:
        Name of the most closer feature, or null if none can be found. The name is returned as the feature name and some data between brackets, like feature type, longitude, and latitude (deg), size (km), and details.

      • identifyFeature

        public static LocationElement identifyFeature(java.lang.String name,
                              Target.TARGET target)
        Returns the position of a feature in the current rendered body.
        Parameters:
        name - Name of the feature.
        target - Target body.
        Returns:
        Location of the feature, or null if it is not found.

      • getListOfFeatures

        public static java.lang.String[] getListOfFeatures(Target.TARGET target)
        Returns a list of features for a given body.
        Parameters:
        target - Target body.
        Returns:
        List of features, or null in case of error.
